. This was a brilliant stroke, but no follow-on troops were allocated to occupy those bypassed areas-and thus to preempt the insurgency that grew up as a result. "In retrospect," Donald Rumsfeld allows, it's possible there may have been times when more troops could have been helpful.... It is conceivable that several thousand more troops in Baghdad, where most of the media was located, might have at least kept the capital from appearing so chaotic, a perception that proved damaging throughout our country and the world ( p. 664, italics added). Amazing. Donald Rumsfeld still doesn't get it. Insufficient troops didn't merely create a perception of chaos; it led to a real breakdown. At the time Donald Rumsfeld
